discourse_list.title: [Discussion] Is GFX's Interest Protocol a Direct Challenge to Maker?

content.content: Maybe I’m just not in the right Discord servers, but I was caught by surprise in seeing this announcement yesterday: a new fractional reserve DeFi protocol launched by GFX Labs, launching as soon as June 13.    Medium – 1 Jun 22    Announcing Interest Protocol GFX Labs is excited to announce that Interest Protocol (IP) will launch on the Ethereum blockchain on June 13th, 2022.  Reading time: 5 min read       It looks like the system is based on an over-collateralised stablecoin called USDi, built to pay yield to all USDi holders (no matter where they got the USDi). The announcement says that the protocol has less liquidity risk than Compound or Aave, but is also highly scalable, using fractionalised reserve banking. “IP applies fractional reserve banking to DeFi by allowing users to deposit USDC into the protocol, issuing USDi to depositors and borrowers, and maintaining a reserve of USDC.” Had a dive through the Interest Protocol whitepaper and page three sees the authors directly compare IP to Maker. The whitepaper claims that there are four differences between the two:  Interest Protocol pays interest to all holders of USDi, while Maker pays interest only through the DSR (when turned on) to DAI staked in the DSR contract Interest Protocol offers cross-margin vaults, versus only single-collateral vaults at Maker Interest rates are determined algorithmically at IP, but manually via governance at Maker Interest Protocol has a “more simple and efficient” liquidation mechanism  It’s obviously early days, but GFX Labs (not least through their Maker and Compound experience) are capable and experienced operators and so I’m inclined to think this new protocol could emerge as a serious player in DeFi. On that basis, even though the protocol is yet to launch, it seems reasonable to discuss whether this protocol could emerge as a genuine competitor to Maker. That comparison seems front of mind for Interest Protocol as well, given a few provocative tweets like this one:   twitter.com    Interest Protocol @InterestDeFi  People have asked, "why is Interest Protocol superior to@MakerDAO?" We could say it is because of multi-collateral vaults, liquidation mechanism, oracle infrastructure, or because IP pays interest to lenders. But there is one main reason: USDi has a stronger peg than DAI.   10:05 PM - 2 Jun 2022           18                2            Would be interested to hear from @GFXlabs on this:  To what extent do they see Interest Protocol as a direct challenger to Maker? Does their launching of Interest Protocol raise a conflict with their role as a significant delegate for Maker?  Any other thoughts or opinions welcome.
Seems more like a swipe at Compound. Didn’t they slow walk to death a proposal to pay GFX for some work a few months ago? Bet Leshner is sad now

The situation bears watching for sure, but how many years would it take for something to actually compete with Maker? Even UST wasn’t born right before being a challenger. Matt_NZ:  an over-collateralised stablecoin called USDi, built to pay yield to all USDi holders (no matter where they got the USDi). The announcement says that the protocol has less liquidity risk than Compound or Aave, but is also highly scalable, using fractionalised reserve banking. “   Maybe I’m missing something obvious and haven’t read their post but which one is it -  fractionalized reserves or overcollateralized?

I think it will take years for any new stablecoin to show they can scale and poses a challenge. It’s not just the set up that matters. Liquidity and integration (such as big exchanges) are also important and these take a lot of effort and resources.

Sorry sorry, but I am getting confused now. Based on this quick review, the USDi contracts allow depositors to receive yield - but the same GFX, through their delegated presence at Maker, is attacking Maker proponents to open a debt vault for DAI holders to deposit them and get paid yield on DAI? Classifying the idea as absurd and fraudulent? Funny.

It’s absurd to think that Maker is the only one who can reliably provide a stablecoin in this ecosystem, especially when innovation at Maker has stalled while we attempt to figure out “governance”. Instead of scoffing at these attempts we should try to learn from what gaps they are attempting to fill and see how we could complement (or implement ourselves).

To clarify, both @GFXlabs and @PaperImperium have devoted a lot of time and resources to help the Maker protocol. So I wouldn’t take it as “Dai will die by my hand” threat. Similar to many protocols that utilize Dai and improve upon it, it’s a way to grow and use Dai.

AstronautThis:  Maybe I’m missing something obvious and haven’t read their post but which one is it - fractionalized reserves or overcollateralized?   I was confused by this as well. The Interest Protocol announcement describes the system as both (emphasis added):  "A fractional reserve bank maintains a portion of its deposits in cash and uses the rest to generate loans. IP applies fractional reserve banking to DeFi by allowing users to deposit USDC into the protocol, issuing USDi to depositors and borrowers, and maintaining a reserve of USDC. Two types of assets back USDi: USDC, which is liquid, and over-collateralized loans, which generate revenue but are less liquid than USDC. Therefore, USDi is an over-collateralized stablecoin. Fractional reserves maintain liquidity; collateralization ensures solvency. Undercollateralized stablecoins such as UST are insolvent by design; USDi, on the other hand, is designed to remain solvent even under adverse market conditions."  This is a tricky thing to reconcile. OK, the loans are over-collaterised, but that doesn’t mean that USDi is necessarily an over-collateralised stablecoin given that there is another way to generate USDi (depositing USDC, some of which is then lent out per their fractional system). Possibly this is where the system’s ‘dynamic interest rate system’ is supposed to kick in to ensure USDi is adequately backed, but it’s not clear to me that that’s a reliable mechanism in adverse market conditions like those that engulfed Terra.

I was replying to Luca’s comment above, but maybe I misunderstood him.

I think your reply reinforces my question. I am not putting in doubt the good faith and ability of GFX - although there are obviously the conflict of interest points that pervade DeFi and crypto in general. My curiosity was driven by the fact that GFX has been so vocal in criticising an informal talk (yield-bearing sub-sets of DAI) while advocating for the same solution across the whole pool USDi. I will look at the evolution of this with interest. I, like you, am convinced that we live in a composable world where one project can and should build on top of the other. And I always start with an assumption of good faith.

As in any company, project or venture that is born, you want it to be sustained over time and be successful. From my point of view it is clearly a conflict of interest for your project vs MakerDAO, because it is not convenient for makerDao to keep going, because your efforts will be concentrated on your protocol. Now, if you define the range of scope of your project, what kind of audience you want to involve and mark those differences if I see it interesting, otherwise it would clearly be a big conflict. It would be something like working on MakerDAO and USDT at the same time.

I had a discussion about this with @ACREinvest on twitter actually:   twitter.com    𝖺𝖽𝖼𝗏 🥩 @adcv_  Interesting case of tokenholder regulatory arbitrage wrt to delegates/board members. Like much of crypto there is no legal fiduciary obligation, in this case to share/tokenholders. In meatspace law usually stops you from serving on board of KO and launching your own soda. […] twitter.com/labsgfx/status…   GFX Labs @labsGFX  1/ Today GFX Labs is proud to introduce the world to Interest Protocol @InterestDeFi Interest Protocol (IP) is the next step in the evolution of DeFi. It inherits most of the strengths of @MakerDAO, @AaveAave, and @compoundfinance while removing weaknesses https://t.co/2Zxtuqx6bb    9:22 AM - 3 Jun 2022           6                1            Here is my two gwei (in Dai of course). I paraphrase much of what I put on Twitter apologies for the redundancy.  I’m not sure what this particular situation would compare to in meatspace. Can a member of the Board of Coca Cola launch a competing soda pop drink and market it as ‘builds on the strengths of Coca Cola Zero’? It might be legally possible but it’s one of those “feels like it probably shouldn’t be”. Even in countries with a slightly different angle on shareholder obligations (e.g. Germany, where a Board answers to the company), it would still feel the same. I don’t like operating on ‘feelings’ though so this is unsatisfying. In crypto of course everything is a bit of a wild west free market, you take the good with the bad. There is no formal fiduciary obligation for board members / delegates to serve the interests of the token holder or company. So what GFX is doing is perfectly ok, namely: serve on the ‘board’ of MakerDAO and build a competitor to MakerDAO - or rather, there are no laws or rules or MIPs against it. I expect it to evolve one of a number of different lines:  Self-regulation Recusal Carve-outs Market forces Legal intervention Rent-creation   1. Self-regulation GFX publicly commits to ring-fence activities relating to Compound Finance, MakerDAO and Interest Protocol. While their intentions may be sincere, how can the public know this is the case in a “Don’t trust, verify” environment without an enforcement mechanism or regulations? An investment bank gets criticism for serving analyst reports on companies they sell advisory business. Though they are behind a Chinese wall with legal repercussions if broken. Despite the apparent potential for ill-doings, people who have worked at banks will explain just how paranoid people are about not ‘wall-crossing’. Maybe a closer parallel is with unregulated consulting business, where one consulting team can and often does work for competing businesses. But in this instance, they are mere agents, not principals of their clients. Often they are hired for the very reason that they have a lot of ‘industry experience’, read, confidential information from competitors.  2. Recusal GFX recuses themselves either from Interest Protocol or delegation to Compound and MakerDAO. Arguably, they had the opportunity to recuse themselves and pick one of Compound or MakerDAO. Why didn’t anyone pick up on this before? Maybe its because the degree of competition is not so direct. You could argue they only compete incidentally. In the case of Interest Protocol, the direct competition (with both) is much clearer.  3. Carve-out GFX carves-out competing governance businesses and venture investments into separate entities with a primary sale to unrelated parties to disconnect the conflict. It solves the conflict but is costly, annoying and forces shareholders of GFX to pick a side essentially which may not be their goal. Also, through their venture investments, they may come to sit in governance roles in competing businesses.  4. Market forces GFX continues serving on boards for competing businesses but tokenholders undelegate governance votes or market participants elect not to use new venture for fear of being caught in cross-hairs. Has to assume participants are minimally rational (are they?). I would love this to be the case, that the market can interpret signals rationally and coldly and picks one over the other.  5. Legal intervention Highly undesirable but there is scope for legal interventions in absence of broader formal DeFi regulation e.g. claiming breach of related laws but not directly breach of Clayton Act for the GFX entity. Case in point, the OpenSea insider trading case, was not on basis of insider trading [edit: securities fraud] (even though it transparently was) but on wire fraud, etc. EDIT: Humble pie, there is no such thing as ‘insider trading’ but securities fraud, timely from Matt Levine. I would absolutely hate for the government to try and weigh in a situation where there is no criminal wrongdoing just an apparent strange confluence of interests that regulators have tried to resolve in other contexts. Regulators only know how to regulate, they are a hammer in perpetual search for a nail. I hope they stay as far as possible from this space until they have no choice but to recognize facts on the ground. Taxpayer funds are much better employed in hospitals and schools.  6. Rent-creation Also highly undesirable outcome where GFX essentially manipulates either their venture investment or their governance responsibilities to maximize rent-creation in one or the other. Market participants don’t notice, no legal consequences are brought, GFX wins at the expense of every other player. Obviously undesirable - I would venture even for GFX if they wish to build a business for the long-run.  7. Other Maybe I missed some other creative alternatives, e.g. GFX tries to have the cake and eat the tokens too and airdrops Compound and Maker tokens in Interest Protocol or similar.  I made some other tangents on contributors/agents, etc but I leave that to Twitter. Relevant sauce from the friends at Skadden: Interlocking Boards: The Antitrust Risk You May Never Have Heard Of | Insights | Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP Hope this is useful in informing a calm, rational and respectful discussion where we assume the best of others until proven otherwise.

Virtually all of the Maker delegated to GFX is from 0xc0583dF0d10c2e87aE1873b728A0BDa04d8b660C, which I am guessing is Rune. So the problem is moot if he undelegates his Maker as he discussed. Otherwise, its just up to that one wallet holder. Not much anyone else can do.

This is a great discussion on a key topic. GFX has not violated at Maker rules as there are very few rules one could violate. @ACREinvest, @christiancdpetersen, @teej  and I have been discussing some of these governance and conflict of interest issues.  They are tricky to address and manage in DeFi but they are important and present serious attack vectors to the Protocol. In the real world a director on a firm’s board of directors have two legal obligations:  (1) Duty of Care and (2) Duty of Loyalty. (1) Duty of care is fiduciary duty requiring directors of a firm to make decisions that pursue the corporation’s interests with reasonable diligence and prudence (2) Duty of loyalty requires that directors of a firm must act without personal economic conflict in making all decisions in their capacities as corporate fiduciaries We should think carefully about these principles and the key risks/attack vectors they address, and how Maker should best address these risks and potential attack vectors.

Eumenes:  In the real world   In the US, GFX serving Maker as a delegate as well as, presumably, on Interest Protocol, would be flatly forbidden: 15 U.S. Code § 19 - Interlocking directorates and officers | U.S. Code | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute I don’t know that I am in favor of overregulating with rules and policies though I might change my mind. I haven’t made up my mind yet what I would do in GFX’s shoes.

Interest relies on ChainLink and Uniswap for Oracles. There was some discussion on Maker Discord about removing the Oracle whitelist and just allowing everybody to use Maker’s oracles. Is it really a great idea to be so generous? Perhaps dssSnog is a more conservative way to go.
Its a tough issue - I dont know the answer but know Maker must thoughtfully address such issues to succeed.  But do believe that “sunlight is the best disinfectant”
I am disappointed that we are resorting to almost witchhunt even before GFX or @PaperImperium give their explanations or clarifications. Let’s not jump to bad faith
Questions or concerns regarding conflict of interest is valid but calls for stepping down or urging to remove MKR delegation to them seems a bit far fetched

I dont think folks are doing that. I just think this points out a bigger issue that Maker needs to address.  And I am grateful that their actions have helped highlight the issue.  I have no issue with their actions as they are well within current Maker standards.

To be clear, I am not saying he should be undelegated over this, I am saying that what the rest of us think doesn’t really matter. If anything, Rune and GFX should have been approached first instead of this going straight to the forums. They are the responsible parties here.

Echoing @Doo_StableLab here. I think frequently people forget how being an open source protocol it opens up opportunities but also competition. That is not necessarily a bad thing. It drives innovation at the edge. Applying a traditional companies lens/approach to Opensource is a basic misunderstanding of how Opensource really works. In Opensource people don’t use your product/solution because you create barriers to entry to competition, the traditional Porter’s approach applied to companies. They adopt your solution because it is the best, most sophisticated and that answers their core needs.
What possible fiduciary duties could a delegate have to Maker? They aren’t “directors” in any sense of the word.
Maybe he doesn’t want to see “MakerDAO” issuing a yield-bearing asset, which clearly would be a violation of US securities laws.
None formally. But every token holder is in some sense a ‘board member’. Delegates are more than most. I’m not focusing on semantics but on form.

Doo_StableLab:  I am disappointed that we are resorting to almost witchhunt even before GFX or @PaperImperium give their explanations or clarifications. Let’s not jump to bad faith   I agree with you on good faith engagement. However, it is also very fair to point out that a Twitter thread like this from a Recognized Delegate with no other explanation on the forum or Discord isn’t exactly putting Maker and DAI in the best light. Whether the claims made by GFX about USDi are true or not is a separate issue.  Good faith engagement is a two way street.

It depends how serious folks view potential attack vectors due to entangled delegates or even big Maker holders. Some parties have and will continue to try to divert Maker’s economic value to their own personal interests and projects. How serious is this attack vector? And if it is a real threat, how should Maker address it?

We have a few basic options to deal with that attack vector.   Talk to the person or people who delegate to those parties.   Make explicit rules against recognized delegates working for competing protocols. Then ostracize or kick out people who ignore those rules.   Make posts on public squares like the forums, hoping to kick up enough bad PR/drama that the relevant parties feel pressured to act.   Personally, I like the first option the most, but three fits Maker’s culture the best.

Still disagree – MKR holders are incentivized to act in their self-interest and in the DAO’s interest but no other motive exists (like duties) to steer their decision making. I think a more apt description is as members in a large member managed LLC, which is different than a board and where there are no common law duties owed by members to each other. In my opinion, delegates owe nothing to the DAO and are mere proxies for the holders from whom they receive MKR. The reason I am voicing my opinion here is to push back on the potential for “narrative creep”. If we start assuming or stating that MKR holders owe some “duty” to the DAO, it becomes easier to ad hominem denounce and attack those MKR holders when they do something that we don’t like or which fails to align with what we want or support for the DAO. For instance, shitting on GFX for their Interest Protocol thing and how it may violate Paper’s “duty” as a delegate/MKR holder then becomes a way to diminish his positions with regard to the proposed debt raise (ie, the DAO offering yield generating financial assets to investors). That’s what we should not want to see. FWIW, I don’t really give a shit about GFX’s thing, which, as Doo noted, will likely fail if they don’t have a team of people working on integrations, etc.
Have you heard of “Dai” and DSR?
I’m glad the DSR has been essentially turned off for years.

Tosh9.0:  The reason I am voicing my opinion here is to push back on the potential for “narrative creep”.   Fair enough that’s one point of view. There are many upsides to having no rules about this and I think we should aim to be as maximally permissive as possible. However it’s also perfectly legitimate to ask whether GFX can credibly be a good steward of both Maker and Interest. I don’t see any ad hominem. My own pov is that I don’t think it was particularly thought through to announce Interest as an improvement on Maker. It begs some perfectly reasonable questions.

Again it should come down to how serious the attack vectors could be against the Protocol, particularly from entangled delegates and MKR whales. Attack vectors that could present serious or even existential risk to the Protocol should be taken seriously whatever their potential source. A Protocol should be anti-fragile period.  Full stop.  Compromising the anti-fragility for ideology isnt a good approach… Reality has a nasty habit of demonstrating why poor business structures and decisions do not work.  Luna is good recent example.

Eumenes:  A Protocol should be anti-fragile period. Full stop. Compromising the anti-fragility for ideology isnt a good approach…   Just to be devils advocate, isn’t this the biggest argument against real world assets? Because they provide much bigger legal attack surface. Personally I think it’s a good trade off, but that’s what some people would respond with. Seems like kicking out one of the few professional delegates would make the protocol a lot more fragile. If we chased GFX off, who exactly will replace them? No offense intended, but clubs of inexperienced college kids and Johnny-come-lately delegates who suddenly remembered Maker exist in a bear market seem like poor substitutes. GFX and PaperImperium don’t seem like they’re only a “fair weather friend” to Maker. One tweet thread shouldn’t outweigh months of work by arguably the most active delegate. Perhaps people who are scandalized should just ask GFX to abstain on any vote on some short, specific list of topics. Or even just loudly remind people of any conflicts as those topics come up. Seems weird we can have anons as facilitators or anons making proposals to fire people, but we can’t give the benefit of the doubt to one of the delegates who has been here since delegation started

AliceinMKRland:  Just to be devils advocate, isn’t this the biggest argument against real world assets? Because they provide much bigger legal attack surface. Personally I think it’s a good trade off, but that’s what some people would respond with.   Definitely a trade-off. A few things: 1. DAI wants to be a money network and frankly crypto is too narrow an ecosystem. Crypto-lending is now a commoditized product, so we must find new territory to capture. Ultimately need to start bridging the gap between meatspace and DeFi. Is the current formulation perfect? No. But we will evolve the RWAP (Real world asset protocol) such that one day it will look nothing like the way structured finance currently looks (a mess of consultants, lawyers, courts, closed ledgers, middle-men etc.). Rather than do nothing, we must start somewhere. 2. I actually think, if you let the game theory play out, having tie-ins with legitimate, regulated incumbents like HVB makes us more anti-fragile, not less. Rather than shedding legacy completely, we are bridging to it, inviting it in. If I were a regulator, I might see good faith.     AliceinMKRland:  Seems like kicking out one of the few professional delegates would make the protocol a lot more fragile. If we chased GFX off, who exactly will replace them?   Many of us believe we are at an inflection point in Maker’s trajectory. Terra model failed—Maker has never been in such position of relative strength. We’ve got a suite of great products to roll out: D3M, L2 MCD, Maker teleport, multi-chain etc. If we execute this growth correctly, Maker is a tremendous success. If we get bogged down in ineffectual governance and navel-gazing, Maker disappears into the red ocean of commoditized crypto-lending. Due to this urgency, we’ve been encouraging large, sophisticated token holders to come out of dormancy.   What have we learned? Voter apathy is driven by complexity. Maker’s product is now too complex for its governance apparatus. Governance will have to adapt in two ways 1) Change the nature of decisions that MKR holders make. More of a Board of Directors (hire, fire, corporate action, budgeting), less like a vote-on-every-little-thing committee 2) Bring a wide set of expertise to the voting bench. I think you’ll see the composition of delegates and active MKR holders change drastically over the next six months. There’s too much to benefit from if the next era is done right. You’re already seeing reputable participants like @Hasu and @mhonkasalo as well as sophisticated funds like Blocktower enter the fray. This will only continue such that all large delegates will have to demonstrate clear value-add towards one or multiple of the domains that underpin MakerDAO’s business lines. GFX is great because they can contend well with the complexity in the trenches. There are many others like this but Maker needs to find a way to condense itself into a form that experts can interact with. The opp. cost to digging through the forums and establishing context is too high for the potential reward. From talking to some of large token holders, there are two ways to drive participation: 1. Information leverage (Dashboards that simplify decision-making like Messari Governor) 2. Delegation: large funds don’t want to do this because it makes them look unsophisticated. It’s on all of us, especially the core units, to find ways to get those most equipped to shepherd the protocol involved.

teej:  It’s on all of us, especially the core units, to find ways to get those most equipped to shepherd the protocol involved.   Not excited about CUs trying to influence the ranks of their own bosses. Particularly given who you provide as an example of “reputable.” But that’s a discussion for another thread because I think I’ve inadvertently gotten us off topic

CodeKnight:  If anything, Rune and GFX should have been approached first instead of this going straight to the forums. They are the responsible parties here.   Can you explain what you mean @CodeKnight that Rune is one of “the responsible parties” here? In any case, strong disagreement that the public announcement by GFX should somehow not immediately be discussed publicly and openly right here on the MakerDAO forum.     Eumenes:  But do believe that “sunlight is the best disinfectant”   Fun fact: my name “Kianga” means “sunbeam,” so it would be doubly fitting to call ACREinvest the “Sunlight Delegate”. There’s nothing whatsoever problematic with community members expressing their views openly here whether deferential to the parties under scrutiny or not. In fact, our resiliency as a project will be enhanced if participants know that their actions may result in a swift public debate rather than a closed-door, private opportunity to deflect criticism.     Tosh9.0:  What possible fiduciary duties could a delegate have to Maker? They aren’t “directors” in any sense of the word.   100% Agree with your sentiment here @Tosh9.0 The higher authority we all need to consider is the one-two punch of long-term stakeholder TRUST & LEGITIMACY. If we fail to sustain these, it’s curtains. We cannot find the perfect set of standards to bear here by looking backward at a failed legacy system. The evidence of that failure is the open door we all walked through to be on this forum in this moment, thanks to a little whitepaper published on October 31, 2008. With that in mind…     adcv:  it’s also perfectly legitimate to ask whether GFX can credibly be a good steward of both Maker and Interest. I don’t see any ad hominem. My own pov is that I don’t think it was particularly thought through to announce Interest as an improvement on Maker. It begs some perfectly reasonable questions.   Yes, absolutely. I appreciated seeing @adcv’s thoughtful Tweet thread Friday that eloquently captured many of my own swirling thoughts and concerns.     AliceinMKRland:  Just to be devils advocate, isn’t this the biggest argument against real world assets? Because they provide much bigger legal attack surface. Personally I think it’s a good trade off, but that’s what some people would respond with.   Important observation @AliceinMKRland! We need to apply this awareness to the substance of every strategic decision going forward, both at the product level but also in terms of delegated Governance and the actions of large MKR holders - something I pointed out on Twitter flagging the RWF team as part of this larger conversation.   twitter.com    kianga.eth 🌍 1000 ACRE DAOs in 1000 Days @fhomoney  🫣 Antitrust & DAOs What are the implications? ⚠️ Especially as@MakerDAO moves into RWA entanglement, has Core Units that are companies. Also am ??? large MKR holders coordinating on voting. What about Delegates only Discord?@CCDPetersen@Lempheter@LucaProsperi@william_remor twitter.com/adcv_/status/1…   𝖺𝖽𝖼𝗏 🥩 @adcv_  sauces and further reading: https://t.co/UC5eTRBSgH    10:18 AM - 3 Jun 2022           1                1            The upshot for me at this juncture is pretty much the following…     Eumenes:  Again it should come down to how serious the attack vectors could be against the Protocol, particularly from entangled delegates and MKR whales. Attack vectors that could present serious or even existential risk to the Protocol should be taken seriously whatever their potential source.   Well said @Eumenes, which is why I have concerns about how we currently have no structure or consensus in place to manage certain unacceptable risks that meat space did figure out were a problem for free and fair markets (with negative consequences for consumers/customers) a long time ago.     adcv:  In the US, GFX serving Maker as a delegate as well as, presumably, on Interest Protocol, would be flatly forbidden: 15 U.S. Code § 19 - Interlocking directorates and officers | U.S. Code | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute   So, while we are doing a NEW thing, we don’t throw the baby out with the bathwater (when it suits us, I suppose). Again, @Eumenes often says correctly, let’s not innovate on ways to lose money as an institutional-grade lender. Similarly, let’s not open ourselves up to be looted by conflicts if we can learn from the past as to better starting point for how to navigate these conflicts in our new Web3 paradigm. Simply “abstaining from voting” doesn’t cut it. The community is not well informed REAL TIME what specific conflicting business interests may comprise the entanglements. And to date I have not seen very much detailed transparency when potential and actual conflicts have been disclosed.     teej:  GFX is great because they can contend well with the complexity in the trenches. There are many others like this but Maker needs to find a way to condense itself into a form that experts can interact with. The opp. cost to digging through the forums and establishing context is too high for the potential reward.   The situation is actually exactly NOT great for the reasons you go on to specify @teej. What you state is fact, so it really does open us up to active engagement from organizations who WILL turn their privileged position of influence, trust and ecosystem access to their own commercial advantage. We cannot just say, oh well - it’s open source so what are you gonna do? Or, well, it’s fine because GFX is talented and smart and we’re happy to have them engaged.     AliceinMKRland:  Seems weird we can have anons as facilitators or anons making proposals to fire people, but we can’t give the benefit of the doubt to one of the delegates who has been here since delegation started   Yes, absolutely @AliceinMKRland we need to address the open proposal process. I speak a bit to that very problem here:    Off-Chain Proposal Bounties Governance       MakerDAO is now too large and complex to continue undifferentiated governance and delegate responsibilities. Vastly more proposals and discussions that are not segmented or categorized for quality and relevance to DAO priorities, needs or otherwise will dilute the effectiveness and robustness of governance as currently structured.  If we are going to protect and provide for the success of the protocol through, for example, scaling sophisticated DeFi versions of RWA TradFi structures, we cannot h…     However, we also do not have the luxury of giving anyone “benefit of the doubt”, all due respect to OGs here. And I DO respect you! Who is going to be aggressive and fierce and push back on anyone on behalf of MakerDAO as a whole (and not just pursue the interests of a specific powerful voting block of MKR tokens)? I suggest we assume folks will pursue their selfish economic interests including delegates and MKR whales.  This is the traditional ‘economic man’ assumption of capitalism.  While its not true of everyone, some folks will certainly behave this way. Given this assumption/reality, what are the key risk vectors to Maker?  And are they large enough additional governance is needed? From what I have seen to date one of the existential threat from such behavior to date has been folks pushing Maker to fund projects that they financial interests in.  This can clearly siphon value off Maker to this other projects unless Maker makes sure any such deal is a reasonable ‘arms length’ transaction.  Currently there are no standards to address this risk and I dont know the best approach to this ‘attack vector’ but transparency and disclosure are a great starting point. There are other entangled attack vectors worth addressing.

Or, to be devil’s advocate (am I using that right everyone?), one of the biggest attack vectors right now is bureaucratic capture, wherein the built-in, day-to-day workforce attempts to demonize one set of constituents (delegates and whales) to promote and harden its positions. Instead of standards and process being set and enforced by the “owners” of the protocol in a consistent and transparent way, new task forces and projects are proposed and new budgets requested that lack that consistency and transparency, but place a large amount of discretion in a small amount of hands. Pretty soon, you’ll be having invite-only meetings and secret pitch decks that the bureaucracy uses to curry favor and align unnamed groups behind closed doors prior to an open vote. You might even find that bureaucracy threatening individuals offline who directly or indirectly object to its plans. Oh wait, that’s already happening… So, while consolidated voting power may be an existential concern that has yet to be evidenced, I think there is a very specific, yet more insidious and less dramatic attack vector already gaining traction. And this is very germane to this post because GFX is not doing anything like what I describe. Someone (or some entity) that owns MKR and actively participates in governance created a side project. That project directly competes (arguably) with another DeFi project, but not yet MakerDAO in any material way. Is it a potential conflict of interest held by GFX - maybe, but there’s no clear competitions yet and a rational economic actor doesn’t cut off its nose to spite its face. So, there would have to be a serious scaling up of the Interest protocol AND some irrational behavior or a MKR sale by @GFXlabs or @PaperImperium for that conflict to materialize. However, the consolidation of control, new opaque process and granting of discretionary budgets to CUs or task forces thereof may constitute an actual conflict of interest depending on what that control is used for, what happens behind closed doors, and whose discretion is exercised for whose benefit. At least we have clear-ish information on the former, but just feints and handwaving regarding the latter. If you’re going to examine conflicts of interest, everyone needs to be in scope. CUs don’t get a free pass - that’s why we have open governance and transparent process.

To be clear - “not all CUs” but nuance is admittedly not a strength of my communications skills. There are plenty of people in the CUs committed to the principles the platform was established with, including maybe some who are unintentionally and in good faith contributing to what I write about. That’s why we all have to check ourselves.
